Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Development of a novel BioNematicide to control soybean cyst nematode
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project proposes to develop a novel bionematicide to control soybean cyst nematode (SCN) in soybeans. In wide-ranging preliminary research, this bionematicide controlled several nematode stages, including up to 90% of cysts (the primary inoculum source for SCN infestations). The isolate also controls SCN over a broad range of soil temperatures and SCN races (biotypes), indicating that resistance to the isolate by SCN will be of minimal consequence. The overall objectives of this project are to 1) demonstrate and determine field parameters for application of the technology and 2) evaluate scale-up production protocol(s) for eventual commercial production. The advantage of the project is supported through the collaborative efforts of a strong public and private alliance utilizing very diverse professional expertise. This alliance provides an excellent framework to design and implement field and laboratory testing as well as marketing (and related) strategies to make the project successful. Results will provide data and structure for an expeditious commercialization track.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that SCN is one of the most economically important disease pest of soybeans in the world. Most chemical nematicides have been removed or are little used, resistant cultivars continue to break down to SCN biotypes, and crop rotation is not feasible in most areas due to economic and environmental constraints of applicable crops. Based on these factors the technology, once commercialized, will have a significant impact in the market. In the U.S. alone, there are 50,000,000 soybean acres (and growing) infested with SCN, costing farmers an estimated $1.5 billion annually. And, because of the environmentally (or "green") sound and sustainable nature of the product, the technology will create much broader impacts for the consuming public through the overall reduction of chemical pesticide applications and by providing for a much needed option in soybean cyst management. Effective, sustainable control methods such as outlined in this proposal are badly needed for this major pest creating a significant market opportunity as well as societal benefits.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of a novel BioNematicide to control soybean cyst nematode

D. Kelly Cartwright, PI

     This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project researched a novel bionematicide to control soybean cyst nematode (SCN) in soybeans.   Under a broad experimental plan, this bionematicide was evaluated in laboratory, greenhouse and field trials to assess potential as a commercial product.  The overall objectives of this project were to 1) demonstrate and determine field parameters for application of the technology and 2) evaluate scale-up production protocol(s) for eventual commercial production.  The advantage (or merit) of the project was supported through the collaborative efforts of a strong public and private alliance utilizing very diverse professional expertise.  This alliance provided an excellent framework to design and implement field and laboratory testing as well as marketing (and related) strategies to make the project successful.  Results provided practical and foundational data related to development of scale-up production, host range, field application rates, molecular characterization and economical viability of the technology.

 

      The broader impact/commercial potential of this project can be significant.  SCN is the most economically important disease pest of soybeans in the world with few options for management.  Most chemical nematicides have been removed or are little used; resistant cultivars continue to break down to SCN biotypes; and crop rotation is not feasible in most areas due to economic and environmental constraints of applicable crops.  Based on these factors the technology, once commercialized, will have a significant impact in the market.   In the U.S. alone, there are 50,000,000 soybean acres (and growing) infested with SCN, costing farmers an estimated 1.5 billion dollars annually.  The market impact would be quick and significant.  And, because of the environmentally (or ‘green’) sound and sustainable nature of the product, the technology will create much broader impacts for the consuming public through the overall reduction of chemical pesticide applications and by providing for a much needed option in soybean cyst management.  Effective, sustainable control methods such as outlined in this proposal are badly needed for this major pest and would have highly significant market impacts as well as societal benefits


Last Modified: 12/06/2011
Modified by: D K Cartwright
